What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a deep knowledge of the history of the art museum, insights into analysis of the museum space, and how to apply these analyses and ideas regarding actual museums that I walk through

I learned about the origins of the art museum, which is foundational to understanding where critiques of the institution emerge today. Issues of restitution and representation extend back in time to the very first cabinets of curiosity, begging the question; how must we go about changing the museum, when the museum itself was built on enterprises of colonialism?

This course offered an overview of the origin and history of museums, interesting topics including national galleries, donor memorials, and museums and empires, as well as crucial topics in contemporary museums, such as de-colonialization, modernism, indigenous art curation. I also learned to curate a temporary exhibition by examples and by practice.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Professor Barringer!!! Simply fantastic. Any class with him is phenomenal.
This course is a wonderful space for discussion and learning. Professor Barringer allows for everyone's opinion and balances lecturing and group discussion very well.

This course is well-organized, covering a wide range of topics with logical connections. The class also strikes a great balance between broad overview and in-depth discussions. The readings are mainly focused on American or European museums, but Prof. Barringer brings in global perspectives in class discussions and presentations and encourages everyone to write about what they care about in individual assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100%! This course is fun, engaging and informative. Every wannabe curator and art historian should take this course!

I would absolutely recommend this course to any art history student or museum enthusiast! This is my favorite art history class so far. We learned about such fascinating and important topics in this class, including the origin and history of museums and crucial topics in contemporary museums, such as de-colonialization, modernism, indigenous art curation. I really enjoyed all the assignments, including group and individual presentations, critical comparison of museum websites, and exhibition proposal. I learned so much in readings and class discussions that I can never look at museums the same again.
Yes, absolutely! Professor Barringer is amazing and the content is very interesting.
